title: Home
text:
Mathew (Mat) Cieśla received his BA (cum laude) in psycholinguistics with a minor in German language and philology from New College at the University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, USA. In 2022, he was awarded the prestigious Fulbright Grant (for independent research) by the U.S.-Polish Fulbright Commission to conduct research at Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznań. Here, he collaborated with Dr. Katarzyna Jankowiak and  Dr. Efthymia Kapnoual comparing neural responses to orthographic and image referents in early-stage second language acquisition. Currently, Mathew holds a position at Northumbria University, Newcastle-Upon-Tyne, UK as as a postgraduate researcher and demonstrator at the Department of Psychology. His Ph.D. work is supervised by Dr. Glenn Williams and co-supervised by Dr. Hazel Blythe and Dr. Vera Kempe.

title: Research
text:
Mathew’s research largely focuses on aspects of lexico-semantic development in late, second language learners utilising electroencephalography (EEG) and event-related potential (ERP) techniques. More recently and as part of his Ph.D. work, Mathew has begun research involving bidialectals (those who speak and are exposed to two or more dialects), and the effects of dialect on primary language education in children. 




Decoding Dialect Density - Development of a new method for the measurement of dialect density using AI. (This project is available on the OSF)
 Cross Language Associative Priming - Understanding how new bilinguals process interlingual homographs.
 FLACON - Exploring the effects of image and orthographic referents on the early stages of late, second language acquisition. (preliminary data of this study was presented at AMLaP and ESCOP 2023, and can be found here)





M2L2 -  Effects of motor encoding on sign language acquisition in hearing adults(read the article here)
